etymology: Disputed;[1][2] possibly from *weh₁y- (“to twist; to wrap”) +‎ *-ō,[3][4][5] compare Ancient Greek ὑιήν (huiḗn, “grapevine”), from *wihy-ḗn[5], and Latin vītis (“vine”), from *wéh₁itis, or perhaps borrowed from either Proto-West Semitic *wayn- or Proto-Kartvelian *ɣwino-, if those terms are not instead borrowings of this one.[2][6][7][8] Possibly all ultimately borrowed from an unattested Mediterranean substrate language.[9][10]
